info.title: Continuous integration and auto-publish to production

chapter.para:
The Rackspace publishing system supports continuous integration and push-button publishing of content to our production environment. Continuous integration refers to the process of performing a sanity build of a set of documents each time a change is pushed to the repository.
Git/Github serves as our source control system. Writers and developers commit changes to their local git repository and then push those changes to a central repository in Github:Enterprise (github.rackspace.com) or Github (github.com).
Jenkins serves as our continuous integration server. When someone pushes a change to the central github repository, Jenkins notices the change and performs a build of the project. If the build is successful, the content appears in our staging servers. If the build fails, Jenkins sends a notification email to a configured list of emails.
We have two staging servers:
docs-staging mirrors the external production environment, docs.rackspace.com, which hosts our customer-facing documentation.
docs-internal-staging mirrors the internal production environment, docs-internal.rackspace.com, which hosts internal documents not available to customers, internal versions of external documentation, and, if internal versions are not provided, the external versions of documents. This internal site is primarily used by Rackspace support and is only accessible on the Rackspace network.
From the staging servers writers can promote documents from staging to production by selecting the document and clicking a button. To view the autopublish UI, browse to the appropriate URL and enter the correct credentials:
docs-staging/publish
docs-internal-staging/publish

section.title: Controlling the placement of links on the landing page
section.para: The landing page for the internal and external staging and production sites consists of a number of boxes for the various products that Rackspace offers: docs.rackspace.com.png

You can control which group a given document appears in and where it appears using metadata in the document:<book xmlns="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" version="5.0-extension RackBook-2.0" xml:id="os-cs-devguide"> <title>Next Generation Cloud Serversâ„¢ Developer Guide</title> <info> <!-- ... stuff omitted ... --> <raxm:metadata xmlns:raxm="http://docs.rackspace.com/api/metadata"> <raxm:displayname>API Developer Guide</raxm:displayname> <raxm:product version="v2">servers</raxm:product> <raxm:priority>20</raxm:priority> </raxm:metadata> </info>
The raxm:metadata element wraps the metadata that controls where the document's link appears on the landing page. This element also binds the prefix raxm with the namespace URI http://docs.rackspace.com/api/metadata.
The raxm:displayname element defines the text to display on the landing page. For example, API Developer Guide, Getting Started Guide, or Release Notes.
The raxm:product element and its version attribute together control which product box the link lands in. Currently supported values are: Product and version values
Product Value Versions
Cloud Servers servers v1.0 or v2
Cloud Databases cdb v1.0
Cloud Monitoring cm v1.0
Cloud Files cloudfiles v1.0
Cloud Loadbalancers loadbalancers v1.0
Cloud Identity auth v1.1 or v2.0
Cloud Sites sites v1.0
Cloud Block Storage cbs v1.0
Service Registry rsr v1.0
SDKs sdks n/a
This value controls the sorting of items within a product. The value is actually a sequence, so the lowest number is the first in the list and the highest number the last. A best practice is to number items with space between so other items can be added later. For example, you might number the first three documents 10, 20, and 30 so that items could be added between later.
